events.title: The Spirits' Schedule, Marley's Departure, and Scrooge's Troubled Sleep
detailed_summary: Marley dictates the schedule for the spirits' appearances: the first at one AM the next day, the second at the same hour the night after, and the third when the clock strikes twelve on the subsequent night.
He instructs Scrooge to remember their conversation for his own sake and says Scrooge will see him no more.
The ghost binds its jaw again with the wrapper.
Scrooge sees his visitor standing erect, chain wound around its arm.
The apparition retreats backward towards the window, which opens by itself as the ghost approaches.
Marley's Ghost beckons Scrooge closer, then holds up a hand to stop him.
Scrooge halts, hearing confused sounds of lamentation and regret from outside.
The ghost joins the mournful sounds and floats out into the night.
Driven by curiosity, Scrooge goes to the window and looks out.
The air teems with restless, moaning phantoms, all wearing chains like Marley's; some are linked together.
Scrooge recognizes many from their lives, including one he knew well, attached to an iron safe, lamenting its inability to help a poor woman and child below.
Their shared misery is their powerlessness to intervene positively in human affairs.
The phantoms and their voices fade away, possibly into mist, returning the night to its previous state.
Scrooge closes the window and checks the door, confirming it is still double-locked as he left it.
He attempts to say "Humbug!" but cannot complete the word.
Overcome by emotion, fatigue, his glimpse of the supernatural, or the lateness, Scrooge desperately needs rest.
He goes straight to bed without undressing and falls asleep instantly.

events.text_segment:
Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One.”
“Couldn’t I take ’em all at once, and have it over, Jacob?” hinted Scrooge.
“Expect the second on the next night at the same hour. The third upon the next night when the last stroke of Twelve has ceased to vibrate. Look to see me no more; and look that, for your own sake, you remember what has passed between us!”
When it had said these words, the spectre took its wrapper from the table, and bound it round its head, as before. Scrooge knew this, by the smart sound its teeth made, when the jaws were brought together by the bandage. He ventured to raise his eyes again, and found his supernatural visitor confronting him in an erect attitude, with its chain wound over and about its arm.
The apparition walked backward from him; and at every step it took, the window raised itself a little, so that when the spectre reached it, it was wide open.
It beckoned Scrooge to approach, which he did. When they were within two paces of each other, Marley’s Ghost held up its hand, warning him to come no nearer. Scrooge stopped.
Not so much in obedience, as in surprise and fear: for on the raising of the hand, he became sensible of confused noises in the air; incoherent sounds of lamentation and regret; wailings inexpressibly sorrowful and self-accusatory. The spectre, after listening for a moment, joined in the mournful dirge; and floated out upon the bleak, dark night.
Scrooge followed to the window: desperate in his curiosity. He looked out.
The air was filled with phantoms, wandering hither and thither in restless haste, and moaning as they went. Every one of them wore chains like Marley’s Ghost; some few (they might be guilty governments) were linked together; none were free. Many had been personally known to Scrooge in their lives. He had been quite familiar with one old ghost, in a white waistcoat, with a monstrous iron safe attached to its ankle, who cried piteously at being unable to assist a wretched woman with an infant, whom it saw below, upon a door-step. The misery with them all was, clearly, that they sought to interfere, for good, in human matters, and had lost the power for ever.
Whether these creatures faded into mist, or mist enshrouded them, he could not tell. But they and their spirit voices faded together; and the night became as it had been when he walked home.
Scrooge closed the window, and examined the door by which the Ghost had entered. It was double-locked, as he had locked it with his own hands, and the bolts were undisturbed. He tried to say “Humbug!” but stopped at the first syllable. And being, from the emotion he had undergone, or the fatigues of the day, or his glimpse of the Invisible World, or the dull conversation of the Ghost, or the lateness of the hour, much in need of repose; went straight to bed, without undressing, and fell asleep upon the instant.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One.”

“Hold your noise!” cried Scrooge, brandishing his ruler. “Come, I’ll to bed. It’s not worth while.”

“Remember what I told you,” said the Ghost. “Remember that, and let me be gone. In heaven, if you please!”

Its hand was open. He saw meek old Marley, in his pigtail, usual waistcoat, tippet, and fur cap, all in their places. Just as I have seen him, many a time and oft. And when I looked, instead of his face, I saw a dense black cloud; second, only a heap of incoherent matter; third, a terrible shape, which, at the first glance, appeared to be a walking child; then grew larger, with its limbs and body of the most disgusting disjectament; and at last, a body of that very shape which I had before remarked to have no kind of resemblance to man or woman. The withered limbs and the distended joints; the measureless despair and sorrow; and the contrast between them and the pale light eyes, if eyes they were, all these were now upon the Ghost.

“Good night!” said Scrooge.

“Good night,” said the Ghost.

It moved towards the window, but Scrooge looked on, trembling, as the ghostly bundle wound its chain around and around its body, as if it were a sufferer from some terrible disease.

The ghostly visitant held up its hand. Scrooge shaded his eyes, and looked, and looked again, but nothing but a mist and fog, and the old bell, which had just tolled, seemed to have a voice in it. The ghostly visitant beckoned to him, and Scrooge, with a trembling hand, held up his own to stop it. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One.”

Ebenezer Scrooge shuddered as the words echoed in the cold, dimly lit room. The voice had come from the air, as if the very walls of his counting house had spoken. He looked around, his breath visible in the frigid air, but the room was empty. The fire had burned low, casting flickering shadows on the walls. He had been alone all evening, poring over ledgers and accounts, and yet now, the silence was broken by a warning he could not ignore.

“Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One.”

The words were not a threat, but a summons. Scrooge had heard of such things in his youth, when his late partner, Jacob Marley, had spoken of the supernatural and the consequences of a life lived without compassion. But Scrooge had long since dismissed such notions as the ramblings of a man too superstitious for his own good. And yet, as he sat there, the chill in the air was not from the fire’s dying embers, but from something else—something unseen.

He tried to shake off the unease, telling himself it was the cold, the loneliness, the weight of the long, lonely years pressing down on him. But the words had taken root in his mind, and he could not rid himself of them. He looked at the clock on the wall. It was nearly midnight. The bell would toll One soon.

As the final chime rang out, Scrooge felt a sudden gust of wind, though the windows were tightly shut. A cold mist filled the room, and from the darkness emerged a figure wrapped in a long, dark cloak. The figure was tall and gaunt, with a face that was both kind and terrifying. It was the ghost of Jacob Marley, bound in chains and shrouded in sorrow.

“Scrooge!” the ghost cried, his voice a mixture of grief and warning. “I am your former business partner, and I have come to warn you. You have no friends but the chains you forged in life. You will be visited by three spirits, each one a chance to change your fate. The first comes to-morrow, when the bell tolls One.”

Scrooge fell to his knees, trembling. He had spent his life hoarding wealth and pushing away those who cared for him, and now, it seemed, the consequences of his actions were catching up to him. He did not know what the future held, but he knew one thing for certain—his life was about to change forever.

chapters.chapter_title: STAVE  TWO. THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS.

events.title: Scrooge Awakens in Confusion and Anticipation
detailed_summary: Scrooge wakes up in complete darkness, unable to distinguish the window from the walls.
He hears a nearby church clock strike the quarter hours, followed by the bell tolling twelve times.
Astonished, as it was past two when he went to bed, he assumes the clock is broken.
He checks his own repeater watch, which also confirms the time as twelve.
Scrooge is bewildered, wondering if he slept through an entire day or if something unnatural has happened to the sun.
He gets out of bed and looks out the window, finding it very foggy and cold, with no signs of daytime activity.
This lack of daytime bustle relieves him slightly, as it means his financial contracts based on days are still valid.
Returning to bed, Scrooge endlessly contemplates the strange events, unable to make sense of them.
Thoughts of Marley's Ghost persistently return, making him question whether the encounter was real or a dream.
He lies awake until the clock chimes three quarters past twelve, suddenly remembering Marley's warning of a ghost's arrival at one o'clock.
Resolving to stay awake, considering sleep impossible anyway, he waits.
He fears he might have dozed off, but eventually hears the clock begin to strike the hour.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When Scrooge awoke, it was so dark, that looking out of bed, he could scarcely distinguish the transparent window from the opaque walls of his chamber.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At length it broke upon his listening ear.

events.text_segment:
When Scrooge awoke, it was so dark, that looking out of bed, he could scarcely distinguish the transparent window from the opaque walls of his chamber. He was endeavouring to pierce the darkness with his ferret eyes, when the chimes of a neighbouring church struck the four quarters. So he listened for the hour.
To his great astonishment the heavy bell went on from six to seven, and from seven to eight, and regularly up to twelve; then stopped. Twelve! It was past two when he went to bed. The clock was wrong. An icicle must have got into the works. Twelve!
He touched the spring of his repeater, to correct this most preposterous clock. Its rapid little pulse beat twelve: and stopped.
“Why, it isn’t possible,” said Scrooge, “that I can have slept through a whole day and far into another night. It isn’t possible that anything has happened to the sun, and this is twelve at noon!”
The idea being an alarming one, he scrambled out of bed, and groped his way to the window. He was obliged to rub the frost off with the sleeve of his dressing-gown before he could see anything; and could see very little then. All he could make out was, that it was still very foggy and extremely cold, and that there was no noise of people running to and fro, and making a great stir, as there unquestionably would have been if night had beaten off bright day, and taken possession of the world. This was a great relief, because “three days after sight of this First of Exchange pay to Mr. Ebenezer Scrooge or his order,” and so forth, would have become a mere United States’ security if there were no days to count by.
Scrooge went to bed again, and thought, and thought, and thought it over and over and over, and could make nothing of it. The more he thought, the more perplexed he was; and the more he endeavoured not to think, the more he thought.
Marley’s Ghost bothered him exceedingly. Every time he resolved within himself, after mature inquiry, that it was all a dream, his mind flew back again, like a strong spring released, to its first position, and presented the same problem to be worked all through, “Was it a dream or not?”
Scrooge lay in this state until the chime had gone three quarters more, when he remembered, on a sudden, that the Ghost had warned him of a visitation when the bell tolled one. He resolved to lie awake until the hour was passed; and, considering that he could no more go to sleep than go to Heaven, this was perhaps the wisest resolution in his power.
The quarter was so long, that he was more than once convinced he must have sunk into a doze unconsciously, and missed the clock. At length it broke upon his listening ear.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When Scrooge awoke, it was so dark, that looking out of bed, he could scarcely distinguish the transparent window from the opaque walls of his chamber. He could see nothing but darkness, and the old clock on the wall, which had been his companion for so many years, seemed to mock him with its silence. But soon, a sound broke the stillness — the deep, mellow tones of the church bell, striking the quarters. One, two, three, four — the bell tolled with a solemn rhythm, and then, as if to confirm the strangeness of the moment, it struck twelve. Scrooge sat up in bed, bewildered. It was past two when he had gone to sleep, and now it was twelve again. He looked at his repeater watch, which confirmed the time with a steady, unwavering hand. Was it possible that he had slept through an entire day? Or had something unnatural happened to the sun? He rose from his bed and peered out the window. The world outside was cloaked in a thick fog, and the cold air bit at his skin. There was no sign of the usual morning bustle — no carts, no footsteps, no voices. The silence was oppressive, but it brought a small comfort to Scrooge, for it meant that the days of his financial contracts were still intact. He returned to his bed, but sleep eluded him. His mind was a whirlwind of thoughts, and the memory of Marley's ghost returned to haunt him. Had it been real, or had he dreamed it all? He lay there, wide awake, until the clock began to chime the three quarters past twelve. Then, with a sudden jolt of memory, he recalled Marley's warning — a ghost would come to him at one o'clock. Resolved to stay awake, he sat up in bed, his heart pounding with anticipation. He feared he might have dozed off, but soon the clock began to strike the hour.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When Scrooge awoke, it was so dark, that looking out of bed, he could scarcely distinguish the transparent window from the opaque walls of his chamber. He could see nothing but darkness, and the old clock on the wall, which had been stopped for years, seemed to have forgotten the time. Scrooge sat up, rubbing his eyes, and looked about him in confusion. He was still in his own room, in his own bed, and yet something was different. The air was colder, and the silence was more profound than usual. He felt a strange unease, as if he had just emerged from a dream that had left him shaken.

He got up and lit a candle, and as the flame flickered to life, he saw that the room was exactly as he had left it the night before. The same books on the shelf, the same ledger on the desk, the same cold, uninviting fire. And yet, Scrooge could not shake the feeling that something had changed. He looked at his hands, and they were his own, but they trembled slightly, as if he had been through something terrible.

He dressed quickly and went down to his office, where he found the door ajar. The clerk, Bob Cratchit, was already at work, hunched over his desk, shivering in the cold. Scrooge entered without a word, and Cratchit looked up in surprise.

"Good morning, sir," he said, trying to sound cheerful.

"Good morning," Scrooge replied, his voice low and hoarse. He sat at his desk and stared at the ledger, but the numbers blurred before his eyes. He could not concentrate. He thought of Marley, of the ghostly chains, of the warnings and the visions. He thought of Tiny Tim, and the boy's trembling voice: "God bless us, every one!"

Scrooge's heart was heavy with regret. He had spent his life hoarding wealth and pushing people away, and now he saw the consequences of his actions. He saw the loneliness, the suffering, the joy that he had missed. He saw the love that he had denied himself and others.

And so, Scrooge made a decision. He would change. He would be kinder, more generous, more compassionate. He would treat Bob Cratchit with respect, and he would help the Cratchit family in any way he could. He would give to the poor, and he would spread joy and goodwill to all.

As the sun rose over London, Scrooge looked out the window and smiled. The world was the same, but he was not. He had been given a second chance, and he would not waste it. He had learned the true meaning of Christmas, and he would carry it with him always.

events.title: Arrival and Description of the Ghost of Christmas Past
detailed_summary: Scrooge counts the chimes: quarter past, half-past, quarter to the hour.
The hour bell tolls a single, deep, melancholy note: One.
Instantly, light flashes in the room, and Scrooge's bed curtains are drawn aside by a hand.
Startled, Scrooge finds himself face-to-face with an unearthly visitor standing right beside his bed.
The visitor is described as a peculiar figure, resembling both a child and an old man simultaneously, as if viewed through a distorting lens.
Its hair is long and white like an old person's, yet its face is unwrinkled and youthful.
Its arms and hands appear unusually long and strong, while its legs and feet are bare and delicately formed.
It wears a pure white tunic, cinched with a beautiful, lustrous belt, and carries a branch of green holly.
Contradictorily, its white robe is trimmed with summer flowers.
The most striking feature is a bright jet of light emanating from the crown of its head, illuminating the scene.
It carries a large extinguisher cap under its arm, presumably to cover the light.

Scrooge observes that the figure's form fluctuates, its belt sparkling inconsistently, and its shape momentarily dissolving or changing—sometimes having one arm, then twenty legs, then just a head, before reforming clearly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Ding, dong!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And in the very wonder of this, it would be itself again; distinct and clear as ever.

events.text_segment:
“Ding, dong!”
“A quarter past,” said Scrooge, counting.
“Ding, dong!”
“Half-past!” said Scrooge.
“Ding, dong!”
“A quarter to it,” said Scrooge.
“Ding, dong!”
“The hour itself,” said Scrooge, triumphantly, “and nothing else!”
He spoke before the hour bell sounded, which it now did with a deep, dull, hollow, melancholy One. Light flashed up in the room upon the instant, and the curtains of his bed were drawn.
The curtains of his bed were drawn aside, I tell you, by a hand. Not the curtains at his feet, nor the curtains at his back, but those to which his face was addressed. The curtains of his bed were drawn aside; and Scrooge, starting up into a half-recumbent attitude, found himself face to face with the unearthly visitor who drew them: as close to it as I am now to you, and I am standing in the spirit at your elbow.
It was a strange figure—like a child: yet not so like a child as like an old man, viewed through some supernatural medium, which gave him the appearance of having receded from the view, and being diminished to a child’s proportions. Its hair, which hung about its neck and down its back, was white as if with age; and yet the face had not a wrinkle in it, and the tenderest bloom was on the skin. The arms were very long and muscular; the hands the same, as if its hold were of uncommon strength. Its legs and feet, most delicately formed, were, like those upper members, bare. It wore a tunic of the purest white; and round its waist was bound a lustrous belt, the sheen of which was beautiful. It held a branch of fresh green holly in its hand; and, in singular contradiction of that wintry emblem, had its dress trimmed with summer flowers. But the strangest thing about it was, that from the crown of its head there sprung a bright clear jet of light, by which all this was visible; and which was doubtless the occasion of its using, in its duller moments, a great extinguisher for a cap, which it now held under its arm.
Even this, though, when Scrooge looked at it with increasing steadiness, was not its strangest quality. For as its belt sparkled and glittered now in one part and now in another, and what was light one instant, at another time was dark, so the figure itself fluctuated in its distinctness: being now a thing with one arm, now with one leg, now with twenty legs, now a pair of legs without a head, now a head without a body: of which dissolving parts, no outline would be visible in the dense gloom wherein they melted away. And in the very wonder of this, it would be itself again; distinct and clear as ever.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Ding, dong!”

The bell rang out with a clear, resonant chime, and with it came a sudden hush in the air. It was the kind of silence that followed a thunderclap or the toll of a funeral bell—deep, expectant, and full of meaning. Ebenezer Scrooge, who had been sitting at his counting house desk, hunched over his books as usual, looked up with a start. The sound had not come from the clock on the wall, nor from any of the many bells that adorned the city of London. It had come from within.

He looked around, his sharp eyes scanning the room. The fire in the grate had burned low, casting flickering shadows on the walls. The candle on his desk had gone out, leaving only the dim light of the gas lamp to illuminate his face. He was alone, or so he thought.

“Ding, dong!”

The bell rang again, and this time Scrooge felt a chill run down his spine. It was not the cold of winter, nor the damp of the city streets, but something deeper, something unnatural. He rose from his chair, his hand gripping the back of it as if for support. The room seemed to darken, the shadows stretching and twisting as if they had a will of their own.

“Who’s there?” he demanded, his voice gruff and low.

No answer came, but the bell rang once more, and with it, the door of the counting house creaked open. A cold wind swept through the room, extinguishing the gas lamp and plunging Scrooge into darkness. He could hear the faint sound of footsteps, slow and deliberate, approaching from the other side of the room.

“Who are you?” he shouted, his voice now trembling with a mixture of fear and anger.

Still no answer, but the footsteps stopped just a few feet away from him. Scrooge strained to see through the darkness, his heart pounding in his chest. Then, from the shadows, a figure emerged. It was not a man, nor a ghost, but something in between. Tall and thin, with a pale, translucent face and a long, flowing robe, the figure regarded Scrooge with a look of solemnity.

“Are you the ghost of a man?” Scrooge asked, his voice barely above a whisper.

The figure did not answer, but raised a hand and pointed to the door. Scrooge followed its gesture, his eyes widening as he saw the words “Marley’s Ghost” etched in the wood. The name sent a shiver through him, for it was the name of his old business partner, long dead and long forgotten.

“Marley?” he whispered, his voice trembling.

The figure nodded, and with a final chime of the bell, it vanished into the darkness, leaving Scrooge alone once more, but forever changed.

events.title: The Spirit's Identity and Purpose Revealed
detailed_summary: Scrooge tentatively asks if the visitor is the Spirit whose arrival was foretold.
The Spirit confirms with a soft, gentle voice that seems distant despite its proximity.
Scrooge demands to know its identity.
The visitor reveals itself as the Ghost of Christmas Past.
Noticing its small stature, Scrooge asks if it represents the distant past.
The Spirit clarifies it represents Scrooge's own past.
Scrooge feels an inexplicable urge to see the Spirit wear its extinguisher cap and requests it to be covered.

The Ghost reacts strongly, questioning if Scrooge wishes to extinguish the light it offers with worldly concerns, stating that Scrooge's own passions contributed to the creation of the cap it is sometimes forced to wear.
Scrooge apologetically denies any intention to offend or having forced the cap on the Spirit.
He then inquires about the Spirit's purpose for visiting.
The Ghost replies, "Your welfare!"
Scrooge expresses thanks but internally thinks uninterrupted sleep would be more beneficial.
Sensing his thoughts, the Spirit corrects its purpose to "Your reclamation, then. Take heed!"
The Spirit extends its strong hand and gently takes Scrooge's arm.
It commands Scrooge to rise and walk with it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Are you the Spirit, sir, whose coming was foretold to me?” asked Scrooge.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Rise! and walk with me!”

events.text_segment:
“Are you the Spirit, sir, whose coming was foretold to me?” asked Scrooge.
“I am!”
The voice was soft and gentle. Singularly low, as if instead of being so close beside him, it were at a distance.
“Who, and what are you?” Scrooge demanded.
“I am the Ghost of Christmas Past.”
“Long Past?” inquired Scrooge: observant of its dwarfish stature.
“No. Your past.”
Perhaps, Scrooge could not have told anybody why, if anybody could have asked him; but he had a special desire to see the Spirit in his cap; and begged him to be covered.
“What!” exclaimed the Ghost, “would you so soon put out, with worldly hands, the light I give? Is it not enough that you are one of those whose passions made this cap, and force me through whole trains of years to wear it low upon my brow!”
Scrooge reverently disclaimed all intention to offend or any knowledge of having wilfully “bonneted” the Spirit at any period of his life. He then made bold to inquire what business brought him there.
“Your welfare!” said the Ghost.
Scrooge expressed himself much obliged, but could not help thinking that a night of unbroken rest would have been more conducive to that end. The Spirit must have heard him thinking, for it said immediately:
“Your reclamation, then. Take heed!”
It put out its strong hand as it spoke, and clasped him gently by the arm.
“Rise! and walk with me!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Are you the Spirit, sir, whose coming was foretold to me?” asked Scrooge.

“I am,” replied the Spirit.

“Why do you trouble me?”

“Why do you trouble *me*?” said the Spirit, with a mild reproof. “You have never troubled me, to my knowledge.”

“Spirit,” said Scrooge, “I don’t know what has directed me hither, but I have come to see you, and to know your purpose in the sight of this child, and this old man, whose Christmas it is. I am not the man I was. I will not be the man I must have been but for this intercourse. Why show me this, if this was only to make me sorrowful?”

The Spirit touched the child’s head, and held it to Scrooge’s side, then drew away the wraps to show an angel in white garments.

“Remember,” said the Spirit, “that it will be *your* doing, whether it is better or worse.”

“Now, if you have a minute,” said Scrooge, “I’d like to know who the child is, and who the old man is, and what this has to do with me.”

The Spirit pointed to the child and the old man, and Scrooge saw that they were the same person, and that the child was himself as a boy, and the old man was himself as an old man.

“Is it possible?” said Scrooge.

“It is,” said the Spirit. “You are the child, and you are the old man. You are the boy, and you are the man. You are the past, the present, and the future. You are the whole of it.”

Scrooge fell to his knees and wept.

events.title: Journey to Scrooge's Childhood and First Stirring of Regret
detailed_summary: Scrooge instinctively resists, wanting to argue about the unsuitable weather, his light clothing, and his cold, but the Spirit's gentle yet firm grasp is undeniable.
As the Spirit moves towards the window, Scrooge pleads, reminding it of his mortality and vulnerability to falling.
The Spirit touches Scrooge's heart, assuring him this touch will sustain him beyond just preventing a fall.
Instantly, they pass through the wall and find themselves on an open country road flanked by fields.
The city, darkness, and mist have vanished, replaced by a clear, cold winter day with snow.
Scrooge cries out in recognition, realizing he grew up there.
The Spirit watches him mildly; its touch seems to linger, evoking forgotten memories, scents, hopes, and feelings in Scrooge.
The Ghost points out Scrooge's trembling lip and asks about moisture on his cheek.
Scrooge dismisses it as a pimple and asks the Ghost to lead on.
When asked if he remembers the way, Scrooge fervently confirms he could walk it blindfolded.
The Ghost remarks on how strange it is to have forgotten it for years.
They walk, Scrooge recognizing every landmark, towards a small market town.
They observe shadows of boys on ponies and carts, joyfully shouting Christmas greetings.
The Ghost clarifies these are mere shadows of the past, unaware of their presence.
Scrooge feels overwhelming, uncharacteristic joy watching them, identifying each boy by name.
He questions his own sudden gladness at the sounds of 'Merry Christmas'.
The Ghost mentions that the school is not empty; a solitary child, neglected, remains.
Scrooge acknowledges this with a sob.
They reach the dilapidated schoolhouse, evoking feelings of cold and scarcity.
Inside a bare, melancholy room, they see a lonely boy reading by a weak fire – Scrooge's younger self.
Scrooge sits on a bench and weeps at the sight of his forgotten childhood.
Every subtle sound in the house deeply affects Scrooge, softening his heart and bringing tears.

The Spirit gestures towards the reading boy; suddenly, figures from Scrooge's childhood reading appear outside the window (Ali Baba, Valentine, Orson, characters from Arabian Nights and Robinson Crusoe).
Scrooge reacts with ecstatic recognition and excitement, surprising even himself.
He identifies the parrot from Robinson Crusoe and shouts greetings to Friday.
Transitioning quickly, he expresses pity for his younger self and cries again.
Drying his eyes, Scrooge mutters a wish, feeling it's too late now.
When pressed by the Spirit, he admits he wishes he had given something to the carol singer from the previous night.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It would have been in vain for Scrooge to plead that the weather and the hour were not adapted to pedestrian purposes; that bed was warm, and the thermometer a long way below freezing; that he was clad but lightly in his slippers, dressing-gown, and nightcap; and that he had a cold upon him at that time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Nothing,” said Scrooge. “Nothing. There was a boy singing a Christmas Carol at my door last night. I should like to have given him something: that’s all.”

events.text_segment:
It would have been in vain for Scrooge to plead that the weather and the hour were not adapted to pedestrian purposes; that bed was warm, and the thermometer a long way below freezing; that he was clad but lightly in his slippers, dressing-gown, and nightcap; and that he had a cold upon him at that time. The grasp, though gentle as a woman’s hand, was not to be resisted. He rose: but finding that the Spirit made towards the window, clasped his robe in supplication.
“I am a mortal,” Scrooge remonstrated, “and liable to fall.”
“Bear but a touch of my hand there,” said the Spirit, laying it upon his heart, “and you shall be upheld in more than this!”
As the words were spoken, they passed through the wall, and stood upon an open country road, with fields on either hand. The city had entirely vanished. Not a vestige of it was to be seen. The darkness and the mist had vanished with it, for it was a clear, cold, winter day, with snow upon the ground.
“Good Heaven!” said Scrooge, clasping his hands together, as he looked about him. “I was bred in this place. I was a boy here!”
The Spirit gazed upon him mildly. Its gentle touch, though it had been light and instantaneous, appeared still present to the old man’s sense of feeling. He was conscious of a thousand odours floating in the air, each one connected with a thousand thoughts, and hopes, and joys, and cares long, long, forgotten!
“Your lip is trembling,” said the Ghost. “And what is that upon your cheek?”
Scrooge muttered, with an unusual catching in his voice, that it was a pimple; and begged the Ghost to lead him where he would.
“You recollect the way?” inquired the Spirit.
“Remember it!” cried Scrooge with fervour; “I could walk it blindfold.”
“Strange to have forgotten it for so many years!” observed the Ghost. “Let us go on.”
They walked along the road, Scrooge recognising every gate, and post, and tree; until a little market-town appeared in the distance, with its bridge, its church, and winding river. Some shaggy ponies now were seen trotting towards them with boys upon their backs, who called to other boys in country gigs and carts, driven by farmers. All these boys were in great spirits, and shouted to each other, until the broad fields were so full of merry music, that the crisp air laughed to hear it!
“These are but shadows of the things that have been,” said the Ghost. “They have no consciousness of us.”
The jocund travellers came on; and as they came, Scrooge knew and named them every one. Why was he rejoiced beyond all bounds to see them! Why did his cold eye glisten, and his heart leap up as they went past! Why was he filled with gladness when he heard them give each other Merry Christmas, as they parted at cross-roads and bye-ways, for their several homes! What was merry Christmas to Scrooge? Out upon merry Christmas! What good had it ever done to him?
“The school is not quite deserted,” said the Ghost. “A solitary child, neglected by his friends, is left there still.”
Scrooge said he knew it. And he sobbed.
They left the high-road, by a well-remembered lane, and soon approached a mansion of dull red brick, with a little weathercock-surmounted cupola, on the roof, and a bell hanging in it. It was a large house, but one of broken fortunes; for the spacious offices were little used, their walls were damp and mossy, their windows broken, and their gates decayed. Fowls clucked and strutted in the stables; and the coach-houses and sheds were over-run with grass. Nor was it more retentive of its ancient state, within; for entering the dreary hall, and glancing through the open doors of many rooms, they found them poorly furnished, cold, and vast. There was an earthy savour in the air, a chilly bareness in the place, which associated itself somehow with too much getting up by candle-light, and not too much to eat.
They went, the Ghost and Scrooge, across the hall, to a door at the back of the house. It opened before them, and disclosed a long, bare, melancholy room, made barer still by lines of plain deal forms and desks. At one of these a lonely boy was reading near a feeble fire; and Scrooge sat down upon a form, and wept to see his poor forgotten self as he used to be.
Not a latent echo in the house, not a squeak and scuffle from the mice behind the panelling, not a drip from the half-thawed water-spout in the dull yard behind, not a sigh among the leafless boughs of one despondent poplar, not the idle swinging of an empty store-house door, no, not a clicking in the fire, but fell upon the heart of Scrooge with a softening influence, and gave a freer passage to his tears.
The Spirit touched him on the arm, and pointed to his younger self, intent upon his reading. Suddenly a man, in foreign garments: wonderfully real and distinct to look at: stood outside the window, with an axe stuck in his belt, and leading by the bridle an ass laden with wood.
“Why, it’s Ali Baba!” Scrooge exclaimed in ecstasy. “It’s dear old honest Ali Baba! Yes, yes, I know! One Christmas time, when yonder solitary child was left here all alone, he did come, for the first time, just like that. Poor boy! And Valentine,” said Scrooge, “and his wild brother, Orson; there they go! And what’s his name, who was put down in his drawers, asleep, at the Gate of Damascus; don’t you see him! And the Sultan’s Groom turned upside down by the Genii; there he is upon his head! Serve him right. I’m glad of it. What business had he to be married to the Princess!”
To hear Scrooge expending all the earnestness of his nature on such subjects, in a most extraordinary voice between laughing and crying; and to see his heightened and excited face; would have been a surprise to his business friends in the city, indeed.
“There’s the Parrot!” cried Scrooge. “Green body and yellow tail, with a thing like a lettuce growing out of the top of his head; there he is! Poor Robin Crusoe, he called him, when he came home again after sailing round the island. ‘Poor Robin Crusoe, where have you been, Robin Crusoe?’ The man thought he was dreaming, but he wasn’t. It was the Parrot, you know. There goes Friday, running for his life to the little creek! Halloa! Hoop! Halloo!”
Then, with a rapidity of transition very foreign to his usual character, he said, in pity for his former self, “Poor boy!” and cried again.
“I wish,” Scrooge muttered, putting his hand in his pocket, and looking about him, after drying his eyes with his cuff: “but it’s too late now.”
“What is the matter?” asked the Spirit.
“Nothing,” said Scrooge. “Nothing. There was a boy singing a Christmas Carol at my door last night. I should like to have given him something: that’s all.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It would have been in vain for Scrooge to plead that the weather and the hour were not adapted to pedestrian purposes; that bed was warm, and the thermometer a long way below freezing; that he was clad but lightly in his slippers, dressing-gown, and nightcap; and that he had a cold upon him at that time. It would have been in vain for Scrooge to plead that the weather and the hour were not adapted to pedestrian purposes; that bed was warm, and the thermometer a long way below freezing; that he was clad but lightly in his slippers, dressing-gown, and nightcap; and that he had a cold upon him at that time. It was all of no use. The ghostly figure, with its spectral hand raised in command, had already begun to move, and Scrooge, with a shudder that ran through his very bones, found himself compelled to follow. The cold air bit at his skin, and the snow crunched beneath his feet, but he could not stop. The ghost moved with a strange, gliding motion, neither walking nor flying, but something in between, and Scrooge, though reluctant, was forced to keep pace. The streets of London were quiet and still, the only sound the crunch of snow and the occasional creak of a frozen shutter. The city was wrapped in a hush, as if the world itself held its breath in anticipation of what was to come. Scrooge's mind was a whirlwind of confusion and fear. He had always been a man of logic and reason, and the idea of a ghost was something he had dismissed as the fanciful imaginings of the superstitious and the weak. And yet, here he was, following a spirit through the frozen streets of London, his heart pounding with a mixture of dread and curiosity. The ghost did not speak, but its presence was enough to command obedience. Scrooge could feel its power, a force that was both ancient and terrible, and he knew that he could not resist it. He had no choice but to go where it led. They passed by the old counting house where Scrooge had once worked as a clerk, and the sight of it stirred a memory long buried in his mind. He saw himself as a young man, hunched over a ledger, his face pale and drawn from the long hours of toil. He had been poor then, but he had been kind. He had had friends, and he had had hope. But those days were gone, and in their place was the man he had become: a miser, a curmudgeon, a man who had turned his back on the world and the people in it. The ghost led him on, past the market square where the carolers sang their songs of joy and goodwill, and past the homes where families gathered around warm fires, their laughter and merriment a stark contrast to the cold, lonely path Scrooge now walked. He could hear the music and the laughter, but they seemed distant, as if they belonged to another world. The ghost stopped at the door of a small, shabby home, and Scrooge, with a sinking heart, realized where they were. It was the home of Bob Cratchit, his poor, long-suffering clerk. The sight of the Cratchit family brought a wave of guilt and shame over Scrooge. He had always treated Bob with a grudging respect, but he had never been kind to him. He had paid him poorly, given him little time off, and shown no concern for his well-being. And yet, Bob had remained loyal, working hard and enduring the cold and the hunger with a quiet dignity. Scrooge saw the Cratchit children playing in the snow, their laughter ringing out like music. He saw Tiny Tim, the youngest of them, leaning on his crutch, his face alight with joy despite his frail condition. The sight of the boy brought tears to Scrooge's eyes, and he felt a deep, aching sorrow in his heart. The ghost did not speak, but it did not need to. Its presence was a silent reminder of the man Scrooge had been and the man he could become. The ghost led him on, through the streets and into the heart of the city, where the lights of the shops and the bustle of the people filled the air with a sense of life and energy. Scrooge saw the people of London as he had never seen them before: not as customers or employees, but as human beings, each with their own hopes, dreams, and struggles. He saw the poor and the hungry, the sick and the lonely, and he felt a deep sense of responsibility for them. The ghost stopped at the door of a church, and Scrooge, with a heavy heart, followed. Inside, the church was filled with people, their voices raised in song and prayer. The sight of them brought a sense of peace to Scrooge's troubled mind, and he felt a strange sense of belonging. He had always been a man of business, but now he saw that there was more to life than money and profit. There was love, and kindness, and compassion. The ghost led him out of the church and into the night, where the stars shone bright and the air was filled with the promise of a new beginning. Scrooge felt a change within him, a shift in his heart that he could not explain. He was no longer the man he had been. He was a new man, a man with a second chance. The ghost did not speak, but it did not need to. Its presence was a silent blessing, a sign that Scrooge had been given a gift beyond measure. And as the first light of dawn broke over the city, Scrooge knew that he would never be the same again.

events.title: Fan Retrieves Young Scrooge from School
detailed_summary: The Ghost smiles thoughtfully at Scrooge's regret and waves its hand to show another Christmas.
The scene changes: Scrooge's former self appears older, the room darker and dirtier.
This older boy Scrooge is not reading but pacing in despair, alone during the holidays.
Scrooge watches anxiously as the door opens.
A little girl, his sister Fan, runs in, embraces her brother joyfully, calling him "Dear, dear brother."
She excitedly announces she has come to take him home for good, explaining their father is much kinder now and has permitted his return.
She tells him he's to become a man and never return to the school, and they will spend Christmas together.
The boy, touched, calls her "quite a woman."
Fan eagerly pulls him towards the door.
The schoolmaster appears in the hall, condescendingly shaking hands with young Scrooge, which unnerves the boy.
He leads them to a frigid best-parlour and offers them very light wine and heavy cake.
He also sends a servant to offer the postboy a drink, which the postboy declines based on past experience.
Young Scrooge's trunk is loaded onto the chaise, the children bid the schoolmaster goodbye willingly, and drive off happily.
The Ghost remarks that Fan was always delicate but had a large heart.
Scrooge affirms this emotionally.
The Ghost reminds Scrooge that Fan died as a woman and had children.
Scrooge confirms she had one child.
The Ghost states, "True. Your nephew!"
Scrooge appears uneasy and confirms briefly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Ghost smiled thoughtfully, and waved its hand: saying as it did so, “Let us see another Christmas!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Scrooge seemed uneasy in his mind; and answered briefly, “Yes.”

events.text_segment:
The Ghost smiled thoughtfully, and waved its hand: saying as it did so, “Let us see another Christmas!”
Scrooge’s former self grew larger at the words, and the room became a little darker and more dirty. The panels shrunk, the windows cracked; fragments of plaster fell out of the ceiling, and the naked laths were shown instead; but how all this was brought about, Scrooge knew no more than you do. He only knew that it was quite correct; that everything had happened so; that there he was, alone again, when all the other boys had gone home for the jolly holidays.
He was not reading now, but walking up and down despairingly. Scrooge looked at the Ghost, and with a mournful shaking of his head, glanced anxiously towards the door.
It opened; and a little girl, much younger than the boy, came darting in, and putting her arms about his neck, and often kissing him, addressed him as her “Dear, dear brother.”
“I have come to bring you home, dear brother!” said the child, clapping her tiny hands, and bending down to laugh. “To bring you home, home, home!”
“Home, little Fan?” returned the boy.
“Yes!” said the child, brimful of glee. “Home, for good and all. Home, for ever and ever. Father is so much kinder than he used to be, that home’s like Heaven! He spoke so gently to me one dear night when I was going to bed, that I was not afraid to ask him once more if you might come home; and he said Yes, you should; and sent me in a coach to bring you. And you’re to be a man!” said the child, opening her eyes, “and are never to come back here; but first, we’re to be together all the Christmas long, and have the merriest time in all the world.”
“You are quite a woman, little Fan!” exclaimed the boy.
She clapped her hands and laughed, and tried to touch his head; but being too little, laughed again, and stood on tiptoe to embrace him. Then she began to drag him, in her childish eagerness, towards the door; and he, nothing loth to go, accompanied her.
A terrible voice in the hall cried, “Bring down Master Scrooge’s box, there!” and in the hall appeared the schoolmaster himself, who glared on Master Scrooge with a ferocious condescension, and threw him into a dreadful state of mind by shaking hands with him. He then conveyed him and his sister into the veriest old well of a shivering best-parlour that ever was seen, where the maps upon the wall, and the celestial and terrestrial globes in the windows, were waxy with cold. Here he produced a decanter of curiously light wine, and a block of curiously heavy cake, and administered instalments of those dainties to the young people: at the same time, sending out a meagre servant to offer a glass of “something” to the postboy, who answered that he thanked the gentleman, but if it was the same tap as he had tasted before, he had rather not. Master Scrooge’s trunk being by this time tied on to the top of the chaise, the children bade the schoolmaster good-bye right willingly; and getting into it, drove gaily down the garden-sweep: the quick wheels dashing the hoar-frost and snow from off the dark leaves of the evergreens like spray.
“Always a delicate creature, whom a breath might have withered,” said the Ghost. “But she had a large heart!”
“So she had,” cried Scrooge. “You’re right. I will not gainsay it, Spirit. God forbid!”
“She died a woman,” said the Ghost, “and had, as I think, children.”
“One child,” Scrooge returned.
“True,” said the Ghost. “Your nephew!”
Scrooge seemed uneasy in his mind; and answered briefly, “Yes.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Ghost smiled thoughtfully, and waved its hand: saying as it did so, “Let us see another Christmas!” At the direction of the Spirit, Scrooge felt himself going backward through time, and turning into his younger self. The room was darker and dirtier now, and the boy Scrooge was older, no longer reading but pacing in despair, alone during the holidays. He looked anxiously at the door, which suddenly opened. In ran a little girl, all in a flurry of excitement, and threw her arms around him, calling him “Dear, dear brother!” It was Fan, his sister. “I have come to take you home for good,” she said, her eyes shining. “Father is much kinder now, and he has permitted your return. You are to be a man now, and never come back here. We will spend Christmas together!” The boy, touched, looked up at her and said, “You are quite a woman, Fan.” She eagerly pulled him toward the door. The schoolmaster appeared in the hall, and, with a condescending nod, shook young Scrooge’s hand. The boy looked uneasy. The schoolmaster led them to a frigid best-parlour, where he offered them very light wine and heavy cake. He also sent a servant to offer the postboy a drink, which the postboy declined, muttering something about past experience. Young Scrooge’s trunk was loaded onto the chaise, and the children, with willing hearts, bade the schoolmaster goodbye and drove off happily. The Ghost looked at Scrooge and said, “Fan was always delicate, but she had a large heart.” Scrooge nodded, his eyes glistening. “Yes,” he said, “she had.” “And she died as a woman,” the Spirit continued, “and had children.” Scrooge swallowed hard. “Yes,” he said, barely above a whisper. “One child,” the Ghost said. “True,” Scrooge replied. “Your nephew!” The Spirit’s voice was gentle but firm. Scrooge’s face darkened. “Yes,” he said, and turned away.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion invents a transitional description of Scrooge "going backward through time" and "turning into his younger self," which is not present in the original. 
- The completion adds emotional reactions and physical details (such as Scrooge's eyes glistening, swallowing hard, and turning away) that are not in the original passage.
- The completion omits the detailed description of the room's transformation, including specific changes to the environment and the sense of decay.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the step-by-step depiction of the room's physical deterioration, such as the shrinking panels, cracked windows, and falling plaster, which sets the scene for the memory.
- The sequence where Fan claps her hands, laughs, and stands on tiptoe to embrace her brother is abbreviated, missing the playful and affectionate actions that characterize their reunion.
- The completion does not include the full description of the schoolmaster's demeanor, specifically the "ferocious condescension" and the effect it has on young Scrooge's state of mind.
- The details about the maps and globes in the best-parlour, and their condition, are omitted.
- The process of the schoolmaster administering the wine and cake in "instalments" is not mentioned.
- The completion does not specify the tying of Scrooge's trunk to the chaise or the visual of the wheels dashing frost and snow from the evergreens.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately describes the Ghost as directing Scrooge to go backward in time, which is not how the transition is presented in the original.
- The sequence of events is slightly altered: the completion condenses or reorders some actions, such as Fan's announcement and the boy's response.
- The schoolmaster's interaction is simplified, omitting the specific emotional impact on Scrooge and the detailed description of the schoolmaster's behavior.
- The dialogue between the Ghost and Scrooge at the end is paraphrased and includes invented emotional responses not present in the original, such as Scrooge's eyes glistening and turning away.
- The postboy's response is summarized rather than reflecting the original's more nuanced exchange.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Ghost smiled thoughtfully, and waved its hand: saying as it did so, “Let us see another Christmas!” At this, the scene before them changed with a suddenness that made Scrooge start. The church bells were still ringing, but the streets were now filled with the bustle of a different time. The houses were older, the people dressed in fashions of a bygone era, and the air was thick with the scent of woodsmoke and the sound of laughter. It was a Christmas of long ago, and Scrooge recognized it at once. It was the Christmas of his youth, the one he had not thought of in many years.

He saw himself as a boy, playing in the snow with his younger sister, Fan. They were building a snowman, their breath visible in the cold air, their laughter ringing out like music. Scrooge’s heart swelled with a warmth he had not felt in years. He watched as Fan, with her bright eyes and golden curls, ran to their father’s house, begging him to let them stay out and play just a little longer. The father, a stern man, finally relented, and the two children danced in the snow, their joy uncontainable.

The Ghost led Scrooge through the streets, past the old market square where the townspeople were setting up a Christmas tree, its branches adorned with simple decorations and candles. Children ran through the snow, their mittens red and their cheeks rosy. The scent of roasted chestnuts and spiced cider filled the air, and the sound of carolers singing in the distance added to the festive cheer. Scrooge, who had long since forgotten the joy of such simple pleasures, felt a strange ache in his chest.

They came upon a small house, its windows glowing with warm light. Inside, a family was gathered around a modest but lovingly prepared meal. The table was set with roasted meats, vegetables, and a plum pudding that looked as if it had been made with care and love. The children were playing with wooden toys, and the parents were laughing and talking, their voices filled with warmth and affection. Scrooge recognized the house at once—it was the home of his old schoolmaster, Mr. Fezziwig, and his wife.

Fezziwig, a jovial man with a booming laugh, was hosting a Christmas party for his employees. The room was filled with music and dancing, and the employees, who had worked hard all year, were now dancing and laughing as if they had no cares in the world. Scrooge, who had once been one of them, felt a pang of nostalgia. He remembered how Fezziwig had treated him like a son, how he had given him a second chance when no one else would. The memory brought tears to his eyes.

The Ghost turned to Scrooge and said, “This is the Christmas of your youth, the one you have forgotten. It is the Christmas of joy, of love, of family. It is the Christmas that made you who you are.”

Scrooge, overwhelmed by the emotions of the moment, fell to his knees. “I have forgotten,” he whispered. “I have forgotten the joy of Christmas. I have forgotten the love of my family. I have forgotten the kindness of others.”

The Ghost knelt beside him and placed a hand on his shoulder. “It is not too late,” it said gently. “You can still remember. You can still change.”

Scrooge looked up, his eyes filled with tears. “I will,” he said. “I will change. I will remember. I will be a better man.”

The Ghost smiled, and the scene before them faded into darkness. Scrooge was left alone, but he was no longer the same man who had begun this journey. He was changed, and he knew it. He had seen the Christmas of his youth, and it had reminded him of the joy and love that had once filled his heart. And now, he was ready to bring that joy and love back into the world.

events.title: Fezziwig's Joyful Christmas Party and Its Impact
detailed_summary: The scene shifts instantly from the school to the busy streets of a city decorated for Christmas.
The Ghost stops at a warehouse door and asks Scrooge if he recognizes it.
Scrooge confirms it's where he was apprenticed.
Inside, they see an old gentleman in a Welsh wig, whom Scrooge excitedly identifies as "old Fezziwig! Bless his heart; it’s Fezziwig alive again!"
Fezziwig checks the clock (seven), rubs his hands, adjusts his waistcoat, laughs heartily, and calls for his apprentices, Ebenezer and Dick.
Scrooge's younger self, now a young man, enters with fellow apprentice Dick Wilkins, whom Scrooge fondly remembers.
Fezziwig announces the end of work for Christmas Eve and orders the shutters put up immediately.
The two apprentices rush to put up the shutters with remarkable speed and enthusiasm.
Fezziwig energetically instructs them to clear the warehouse space for a party.
The warehouse is quickly transformed into a snug, warm, bright ballroom.
Guests arrive: a fiddler, Mrs. Fezziwig, the three beaming Miss Fezziwigs, their suitors, employees, neighbours, including the housemaid, baker, cook, milkman, and others.
A lively dance begins with many couples.
More dances, forfeits, cake, negus, roast, boiled meats, mince-pies, and beer follow.
The highlight is when Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig lead the dance "Sir Roger de Coverley" with impressive energy and skill.
The party concludes at eleven; Mr. and Mrs. Fezziwig stand at the door, shaking hands and wishing Merry Christmas to every departing guest, including the apprentices.
Throughout this scene, Scrooge is completely absorbed, reliving the memories with intense emotion and agitation.
Only when his former self and Dick turn away does he remember the Ghost watching him.
The Ghost remarks dismissively that it took only a small expense for Fezziwig to earn such gratitude.

Scrooge passionately refutes this, arguing Fezziwig's true power lay not in money spent, but in his ability to bring happiness and make their work pleasant through kind words and actions, a happiness worth a fortune.
Catching the Spirit's gaze, Scrooge stops.
When asked what's wrong, Scrooge denies anything specific but admits he wishes he could speak to his clerk right then.

events.text_segment:
Although they had but that moment left the school behind them, they were now in the busy thoroughfares of a city, where shadowy passengers passed and repassed; where shadowy carts and coaches battled for the way, and all the strife and tumult of a real city were. It was made plain enough, by the dressing of the shops, that here too it was Christmas time again; but it was evening, and the streets were lighted up.
The Ghost stopped at a certain warehouse door, and asked Scrooge if he knew it.
“Know it!” said Scrooge. “Was I apprenticed here!”
They went in. At sight of an old gentleman in a Welsh wig, sitting behind such a high desk, that if he had been two inches taller he must have knocked his head against the ceiling, Scrooge cried in great excitement:
“Why, it’s old Fezziwig! Bless his heart; it’s Fezziwig alive again!”
Old Fezziwig laid down his pen, and looked up at the clock, which pointed to the hour of seven. He rubbed his hands; adjusted his capacious waistcoat; laughed all over himself, from his shoes to his organ of benevolence; and called out in a comfortable, oily, rich, fat, jovial voice:
“Yo ho, there! Ebenezer! Dick!”
Scrooge’s former self, now grown a young man, came briskly in, accompanied by his fellow-’prentice.
“Dick Wilkins, to be sure!” said Scrooge to the Ghost. “Bless me, yes. There he is. He was very much attached to me, was Dick. Poor Dick! Dear, dear!”
“Yo ho, my boys!” said Fezziwig. “No more work to-night. Christmas Eve, Dick. Christmas, Ebenezer! Let’s have the shutters up,” cried old Fezziwig, with a sharp clap of his hands, “before a man can say Jack Robinson!”
You wouldn’t believe how those two fellows went at it! They charged into the street with the shutters—one, two, three—had ’em up in their places—four, five, six—barred ’em and pinned ’em—seven, eight, nine—and came back before you could have got to twelve, panting like race-horses.
“Hilli-ho!” cried old Fezziwig, skipping down from the high desk, with wonderful agility. “Clear away, my lads, and let’s have lots of room here! Hilli-ho, Dick! Chirrup, Ebenezer!”
Clear away! There was nothing they wouldn’t have cleared away, or couldn’t have cleared away, with old Fezziwig looking on. It was done in a minute. Every movable was packed off, as if it were dismissed from public life for evermore; the floor was swept and watered, the lamps were trimmed, fuel was heaped upon the fire; and the warehouse was as snug, and warm, and dry, and bright a ball-room, as you would desire to see upon a winter’s night.
In came a fiddler with a music-book, and went up to the lofty desk, and made an orchestra of it, and tuned like fifty stomach-aches. In came Mrs. Fezziwig, one vast substantial smile. In came the three Miss Fezziwigs, beaming and lovable. In came the six young followers whose hearts they broke. In came all the young men and women employed in the business. In came the housemaid, with her cousin, the baker. In came the cook, with her brother’s particular friend, the milkman. In came the boy from over the way, who was suspected of not having board enough from his master; trying to hide himself behind the girl from next door but one, who was proved to have had her ears pulled by her mistress. In they all came, one after another; some shyly, some boldly, some gracefully, some awkwardly, some pushing, some pulling; in they all came, anyhow and everyhow. Away they all went, twenty couple at once; hands half round and back again the other way; down the middle and up again; round and round in various stages of affectionate grouping; old top couple always turning up in the wrong place; new top couple starting off again, as soon as they got there; all top couples at last, and not a bottom one to help them! When this result was brought about, old Fezziwig, clapping his hands to stop the dance, cried out, “Well done!” and the fiddler plunged his hot face into a pot of porter, especially provided for that purpose. But scorning rest, upon his reappearance, he instantly began again, though there were no dancers yet, as if the other fiddler had been carried home, exhausted, on a shutter, and he were a bran-new man resolved to beat him out of sight, or perish.
There were more dances, and there were forfeits, and more dances, and there was cake, and there was negus, and there was a great piece of Cold Roast, and there was a great piece of Cold Boiled, and there were mince-pies, and plenty of beer. But the great effect of the evening came after the Roast and Boiled, when the fiddler (an artful dog, mind! The sort of man who knew his business better than you or I could have told it him!) struck up “Sir Roger de Coverley.” Then old Fezziwig stood out to dance with Mrs. Fezziwig. Top couple, too; with a good stiff piece of work cut out for them; three or four and twenty pair of partners; people who were not to be trifled with; people who would dance, and had no notion of walking.
But if they had been twice as many—ah, four times—old Fezziwig would have been a match for them, and so would Mrs. Fezziwig. As to her, she was worthy to be his partner in every sense of the term. If that’s not high praise, tell me higher, and I’ll use it. A positive light appeared to issue from Fezziwig’s calves. They shone in every part of the dance like moons. You couldn’t have predicted, at any given time, what would have become of them next. And when old Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig had gone all through the dance; advance and retire, both hands to your partner, bow and curtsey, corkscrew, thread-the-needle, and back again to your place; Fezziwig “cut”—cut so deftly, that he appeared to wink with his legs, and came upon his feet again without a stagger.
When the clock struck eleven, this domestic ball broke up. Mr. and Mrs. Fezziwig took their stations, one on either side of the door, and shaking hands with every person individually as he or she went out, wished him or her a Merry Christmas. When everybody had retired but the two ’prentices, they did the same to them; and thus the cheerful voices died away, and the lads were left to their beds; which were under a counter in the back-shop.
During the whole of this time, Scrooge had acted like a man out of his wits. His heart and soul were in the scene, and with his former self. He corroborated everything, remembered everything, enjoyed everything, and underwent the strangest agitation. It was not until now, when the bright faces of his former self and Dick were turned from them, that he remembered the Ghost, and became conscious that it was looking full upon him, while the light upon its head burnt very clear.
“A small matter,” said the Ghost, “to make these silly folks so full of gratitude.”
“Small!” echoed Scrooge.
The Spirit signed to him to listen to the two apprentices, who were pouring out their hearts in praise of Fezziwig: and when he had done so, said,
“Why! Is it not? He has spent but a few pounds of your mortal money: three or four perhaps. Is that so much that he deserves this praise?”
“It isn’t that,” said Scrooge, heated by the remark, and speaking unconsciously like his former, not his latter, self. “It isn’t that, Spirit. He has the power to render us happy or unhappy; to make our service light or burdensome; a pleasure or a toil. Say that his power lies in words and looks; in things so slight and insignificant that it is impossible to add and count ’em up: what then? The happiness he gives, is quite as great as if it cost a fortune.”
He felt the Spirit’s glance, and stopped.
“What is the matter?” asked the Ghost.
“Nothing particular,” said Scrooge.
“Something, I think?” the Ghost insisted.
“No,” said Scrooge, “No. I should like to be able to say a word or two to my clerk just now. That’s all.”

The Ghost stopped at a warehouse door, and asked Scrooge if he knew it.

"I do," returned Scrooge. "I know it well. It is old Fezziwig's warehouse. I was brought up in the town, Mr. Marley, and have grown up making a great many friends and acquaintances in it."

"Poor old Fezziwig!" said the Ghost.

"Bless his heart; it's Fezziwig alive again!" cried Scrooge.

The old gentleman in a Welsh wig, who conducted the affairs of the old company, came in. He was a fat, jolly, red-faced old gentleman, with a high voice and a high colour, in a state of perpetual good humour; and he spoke to the apprentices as if they were his own children.

"Seven o'clock!" said Fezziwig. "And a merry Christmas to you all!" He had a merry time of it, and a merry way of saying it.

"Ebenezer!" said Fezziwig, "and Dick Wilkins!"

Young Scrooge and his fellow apprentice came in, and Fezziwig, with a great deal of ceremony, shook hands with them both, and said he was very glad to see them.

"Now, my lads," said Fezziwig, "you may go and shut up the warehouse, and come back in an hour's time. I have a little business to attend to, and I shall be at home by that time.

Although they had but that moment left the school behind them, they were now in the busy thoroughfares of a city, where shadowy passengers passed and repassed; where shadowy carts and coaches battled for the way, and all the strife and tumult of a real city were. The Ghost stopped at a warehouse door, and asked Scrooge if he knew it.

"I do," returned Scrooge. "I know it well. It is old Fezziwig's warehouse. I was brought up in the town, Mr. Marley, and have grown up making a great many friends and acquaintances in it."

"Poor old Fezziwig!" said the Ghost.

"Bless his heart; it's Fezziwig alive again!" cried Scrooge.

The old gentleman in a Welsh wig, who conducted the affairs of the old company, came in. He was a fat, jolly, red-faced old gentleman, with a high voice and a high colour, in a state of perpetual good humour; and he spoke to the apprentices as if they were his own children.

"Seven o'clock!" said Fezziwig. "And a merry Christmas to you all!" He had a merry time of it, and a merry way of saying it.

"Ebenezer!" said Fezziwig, "and Dick Wilkins!"

Young Scrooge and his fellow apprentice came in, and Fezziwig, with a great deal of ceremony, shook hands with them both, and said he was very glad to see them.

events.title: Belle Ends Her Engagement to Scrooge
detailed_summary: As Scrooge voices his wish regarding his clerk, his former self dims the lamps, and he finds himself beside the Ghost in the open air again.
The Spirit announces its time is short and urges haste.
The scene changes, showing Scrooge again, but older, in his prime, his face beginning to show lines of care and avarice, with a greedy look in his eye.
He is not alone; a fair young woman named Belle, wearing mourning clothes, sits beside him with tears in her eyes.
Belle softly tells him that another idol, a golden one, has replaced her in his heart.
She states she has no cause to grieve if this new idol can comfort him as she would have tried to.
Scrooge asks what idol she means, and she confirms it is gold.
He defends his pursuit of wealth as a reaction against the world's harshness towards poverty.
Belle gently counters that he fears the world too much, and all his hopes have merged into acquiring wealth, letting his nobler aspirations die.
Scrooge retorts defensively, questioning if becoming wiser means he has changed towards her.
Belle shakes her head, asserting that he has changed significantly since their engagement, which was made when they were both poor and content.
She argues that what promised happiness then is now fraught with misery because they are fundamentally different people.
She asks rhetorically if he has ever sought release from their engagement.

When he asks how, she explains his release was sought not in words, but in his changed nature, altered spirit, different life focus, and the shift in his ultimate hope towards Gain, which devalued her love in his eyes.
She challenges him: if they were unattached, would he seek out and try to win her, a dowerless girl, now?
Scrooge seems to concede the point but struggles, saying, "You think not."

Belle affirms she knows he wouldn't choose her now, or if he did momentarily betray his principle of Gain, regret would follow; therefore, she releases him with a full heart, for the love of the man he used to be.
As he is about to speak, she turns away and continues.
She hopes he might feel brief pain from this memory but predicts he will quickly dismiss it as an unprofitable dream.
She wishes him happiness in his chosen life and departs.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His former self turned down the lamps as he gave utterance to the wish; and Scrooge and the Ghost again stood side by side in the open air.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She left him, and they parted.

events.text_segment:
His former self turned down the lamps as he gave utterance to the wish; and Scrooge and the Ghost again stood side by side in the open air.
“My time grows short,” observed the Spirit. “Quick!”
This was not addressed to Scrooge, or to any one whom he could see, but it produced an immediate effect. For again Scrooge saw himself. He was older now; a man in the prime of life. His face had not the harsh and rigid lines of later years; but it had begun to wear the signs of care and avarice. There was an eager, greedy, restless motion in the eye, which showed the passion that had taken root, and where the shadow of the growing tree would fall.
He was not alone, but sat by the side of a fair young girl in a mourning-dress: in whose eyes there were tears, which sparkled in the light that shone out of the Ghost of Christmas Past.
“It matters little,” she said, softly. “To you, very little. Another idol has displaced me; and if it can cheer and comfort you in time to come, as I would have tried to do, I have no just cause to grieve.”
“What Idol has displaced you?” he rejoined.
“A golden one.”
“This is the even-handed dealing of the world!” he said. “There is nothing on which it is so hard as poverty; and there is nothing it professes to condemn with such severity as the pursuit of wealth!”
“You fear the world too much,” she answered, gently. “All your other hopes have merged into the hope of being beyond the chance of its sordid reproach. I have seen your nobler aspirations fall off one by one, until the master-passion, Gain, engrosses you. Have I not?”
“What then?” he retorted. “Even if I have grown so much wiser, what then? I am not changed towards you.”
She shook her head.
“Am I?”
“Our contract is an old one. It was made when we were both poor and content to be so, until, in good season, we could improve our worldly fortune by our patient industry. You are changed. When it was made, you were another man.”
“I was a boy,” he said impatiently.
“Your own feeling tells you that you were not what you are,” she returned. “I am. That which promised happiness when we were one in heart, is fraught with misery now that we are two. How often and how keenly I have thought of this, I will not say. It is enough that I have thought of it, and can release you.”
“Have I ever sought release?”
“In words. No. Never.”
“In what, then?”
“In a changed nature; in an altered spirit; in another atmosphere of life; another Hope as its great end. In everything that made my love of any worth or value in your sight. If this had never been between us,” said the girl, looking mildly, but with steadiness, upon him; “tell me, would you seek me out and try to win me now? Ah, no!”
He seemed to yield to the justice of this supposition, in spite of himself. But he said with a struggle, “You think not.”
“I would gladly think otherwise if I could,” she answered, “Heaven knows! When I have learned a Truth like this, I know how strong and irresistible it must be. But if you were free to-day, to-morrow, yesterday, can even I believe that you would choose a dowerless girl—you who, in your very confidence with her, weigh everything by Gain: or, choosing her, if for a moment you were false enough to your one guiding principle to do so, do I not know that your repentance and regret would surely follow? I do; and I release you. With a full heart, for the love of him you once were.”
He was about to speak; but with her head turned from him, she resumed.
“You may—the memory of what is past half makes me hope you will—have pain in this. A very, very brief time, and you will dismiss the recollection of it, gladly, as an unprofitable dream, from which it happened well that you awoke. May you be happy in the life you have chosen!”
She left him, and they parted.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
His former self turned down the lamps as he gave utterance to the wish; and Scrooge and the Ghost again stood side by side in the open air.

"Your time is short," said the Spirit, "so let us go together."

In a moment they were in the old city, where the houses, which had grown larger, were very like the houses of the town Scrooge had known; and the people, who had grown older, were very like the people of the town Scrooge had known. But there was a change in Scrooge. He was not the man he had been. He was older, and his face was lined with care and avarice, and his eyes were sharp and keen with the look of one who had long been in the habit of looking out for himself.

He was not alone. A fair young woman, in mourning, sat beside him, with tears in her eyes.

"You have forgotten me," she said, in a low voice.

"No, Belle," said Scrooge, "I have not forgotten you."

"You have forgotten me," she repeated, "and you have forgotten yourself. Another idol has displaced me in your heart."

"What idol?" asked Scrooge.

"Gold," she answered.

"I have no gold," said Scrooge, "I have only the world's hard heart against me."

"You fear the world too much," said Belle. "All your hopes have merged into the hope of getting rich, and your nobler aspirations have died."

"Have I changed towards you?" asked Scrooge, in a tone of defence.

"You have changed greatly," said Belle. "You were once a kind and generous man, and I was your betrothed. We were poor, but we were happy. Now you are rich, and I am alone."

"Have I ever sought to break our engagement?" asked Scrooge.

"Not in words," said Belle, "but in your changed nature, in your altered spirit, in your different life, in the change of your ultimate hope from me to Gain."

"If we were unattached now, would you seek me out and try to win me, a dowerless girl?" asked Belle.

Scrooge hesitated. "You think not," he said at last.

"I know you would not," said Belle. "And if you did, you would soon regret it, for you have made Gain your god."

"Then I am free," said Scrooge.

"You are free," said Belle, "and I release you with a full heart, for the love of the man you used to be."

As he was about to speak, she turned away.

"I hope you may feel some pain from this memory," she said, "but I know you will soon dismiss it as an unprofitable dream."

"I hope you may be happy," said Scrooge.

"I hope you may be happy," said Belle, and she went away.
